title: September 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about ancient proteins, aging mice, mosquito nets, resourceful plants and cocktail party conversations.

chapters.title: Going back in time
chapters.impact_statement: Fragments of ancient proteins are preserved in ostrich eggshells

chapters.title: Good listeners
chapters.impact_statement: Exploring the neuroscience of the cocktail party effect

chapters.title: Great expectations
chapters.impact_statement: The drug rapamycin increases life expectancy in middle-aged mice

chapters.title: Net gains
chapters.impact_statement: Modelling the effectiveness of bednets against mosquitoes and malaria

chapters.title: Dry spells
chapters.impact_statement: The ways that plants respond to drought can be changed

title: July/August 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about human height, fish joints, colour vision, chimpanzees using tools and open science.

chapters.title: Tall story
chapters.impact_statement: A large scale study reveals how human height has changed in the last 100 years

chapters.title: Joint secrets
chapters.impact_statement: Zebrafish have lubricated joints similar to those in humans and other land animals

chapters.title: Seeing things clearly
chapters.impact_statement: Birds tune their light sensitive cells to maximise the number of colours they see

chapters.title: Making the effort
chapters.impact_statement: Travel motivates chimpanzees to use tools

chapters.title: In the open
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers can benefit from making their research findings freely available online

title: June 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about drug production, early career researchers, honeybees, human migrations and pain.

chapters.title: Green drug factories
chapters.impact_statement: A new way to produce a malaria drug using tobacco plants

chapters.title: Lost generation
chapters.impact_statement: Is science at risk of losing talented researchers to other professions?

chapters.title: Secrets of flight
chapters.impact_statement: Honeybees adjust the position of their antennae as they fly

chapters.title: On the move
chapters.impact_statement: How humans have migrated around Africa in the last 10,000 years

chapters.title: Thinking of pain
chapters.impact_statement: Brain imaging reveals how we experience someone else’s pain

title: April/May 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about parasitic worms, dog tumours, epilepsy, DNA sequencing classes and social behaviour in mice.

chapters.title: Building barriers
chapters.impact_statement: How stem cells help parasitic worms to thrive in their host

chapters.title: Going global
chapters.impact_statement: Genetics reveals how an 11,000 year-old dog cancer has spread around the world

chapters.title: New hope for epilepsy
chapters.impact_statement: Drugs that block the hormone oestrogen have the potential to treat seizures

chapters.title: Training the next generation
chapters.impact_statement: University students gain hands-on experience of a new DNA sequencing technology

chapters.title: Gut feeling
chapters.impact_statement: Microbes in the gut influence the social behaviour of mice

title: March 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about aging, artificial fingertips, ancient DNA, antibiotic resistance and dengue fever.

chapters.title: Gender divide
chapters.impact_statement: The guts of male and female fruit flies age differently

chapters.title: Feeling better
chapters.impact_statement: An artificial fingertip can recreate a sense of touch

chapters.title: Why did plagues stop?
chapters.impact_statement: DNA from 18th century teeth reveals plague secrets

chapters.title: Following the food chain
chapters.impact_statement: Genomics can track antibiotic resistance during beef production

chapters.title: Risk assessment
chapters.impact_statement: An early warning system for dengue fever

title: January/February 2016
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about midnight snacking, X-ray imaging of fossils, hummingbirds, monkeys gambling and axolotls regenerating.

chapters.title: Food for thought
chapters.impact_statement: Moving meal times can disrupt learning and memory

chapters.title: Beneath the surface
chapters.impact_statement: X-rays can reveal the internal anatomical details of certain fossils

chapters.title: Up in the air
chapters.impact_statement: Burst muscle capacity is the key to maneuverability for hummingbirds

chapters.title: Decisions decisions
chapters.impact_statement: Two trained monkeys and a gambling task

chapters.title: Going back in time
chapters.impact_statement: Neural stem cells in injured axolotls behave like embryonic cells

title: December 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about heat-seeking behaviour in mosquitos, mass spawning in coral reefs, social organization in ants, fear in rats and tissue regeneration in newts.

chapters.title: Feel the heat
chapters.impact_statement: Mosquitos identify human targets by detecting body heat.

chapters.title: For one night only
chapters.impact_statement: How can more than 100 different species of coral spawn at the same time?

chapters.title: Have no fear
chapters.impact_statement: Male rats and female rats respond to stress in different ways.

chapters.title: An evolutionary conundrum
chapters.impact_statement: How can natural selection favor the evolution of non-reproductive worker ants?

chapters.title: The eyes have it
chapters.impact_statement: Newts can undergo as many as 19 lens regeneration events.

title: November 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about deep-sea bacteria, cigarette smoke and lung disease, antibiotic resistance, unconscious perception, and the benefits of sleep.

chapters.title: Friends or foe?
chapters.impact_statement: Why do the bacteria in deep-sea mussels have so many toxin-like genes?

chapters.title: Dark materials in the lung
chapters.impact_statement: The elemental carbon in cigarette smoke causes inflammation and emphysema in the lung.

chapters.title: Highs and lows
chapters.impact_statement: A mathematical model has been used to explore different approaches to minimizing antibiotic resistance.

chapters.title: Sleep on it
chapters.impact_statement: A nap during the day helps with the retention of important memories.

chapters.title: Now you see it
chapters.impact_statement: Unconscious perception does not exist.

title: September/October 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about Parkinson's Disease, depression, chickenpox, bats, beetles, and how small prey can escape larger predators.

chapters.title: Model behaviour
chapters.impact_statement: Exploring the links between the chickenpox vaccination and shingles.

chapters.title: Sounds good
chapters.impact_statement: Some bats rely on the detection of acoustic shadows to locate their prey.

chapters.title: Catch me if you can
chapters.impact_statement: Small animals can escape larger predators by exploiting their ability to turn more rapidly.

chapters.title: Good and bad parents
chapters.impact_statement: The quality of parenting received by young beetles influences how they look after their own larvae.

chapters.title: A close look at Parkinson's
chapters.impact_statement: The distribution of brain atrophy in patients with Parkinson's Disease has a network structure.

chapters.title: Stress and depression
chapters.impact_statement: The region of the brain that links stress and depression has been identified.

title: SPECIAL EPISODE: Meet Homo naledi
impact_statement: In this special episode of the eLife podcast we hear about a new human species, Homo naledi, that has been unearthed from the Rising Star cave system in South Africa.

chapters.title: Homo naledi, a new species of the genus Homo from the Dinaledi Chamber, South Africa
Geological and taphonomic context for the new hominin species Homo naledi from the Dinaledi Chamber, South Africa
Human evolution: The many mysteries of Homo naledi

title: July/August 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about cancer, dengue fever, sperm DNA and neurons that are sensitive to magnetic fields.

chapters.title: A neurological compass
chapters.impact_statement: Neurons in worms can sense the earth's magnetic field.

chapters.title: Mutations go it alone
chapters.impact_statement: How hyper-loading might make cancers kill themselves.

chapters.title: Getting into shape
chapters.impact_statement: Sperm DNA must undergo major changes before mitosis.

chapters.title: Mapping mosquitos
chapters.impact_statement: Closing in on Dengue fever and chikungunya fever.

title: June 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about tinnitus and hyperacusis, salamanders, chemical harpoons, and the role of ultrasound and song in the mating rituals of mice and flies.

chapters.title: Listen up!
chapters.impact_statement: What causes tinnitus and hyperacusis?

chapters.title: Forever young
chapters.impact_statement: How do salamanders survive repeated amputation of their limbs?

chapters.title: Check mate
chapters.impact_statement: Mice use ultrasound to communicate during courtship.

chapters.title: It takes two
chapters.impact_statement: Flies get to grips with acoustic duetting.

chapters.title: Chemical harpoons
chapters.impact_statement: Covalent bonds help bacteria stick to tissue.

title: April/May 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about echolocation, bacteriophages, babies and pain, a neural code for food abundance, and how zebrafish can make their own sunscreen.

chapters.title: How do babies feel pain?
chapters.impact_statement: Functional MRI suggests that infants and adults experience pain in very similar ways.

chapters.title: A cast of thousands
chapters.impact_statement: More than 2000 students have helped shed new light on the genomics of bacteriophages.

chapters.title: Clicking into place
chapters.impact_statement: Porpoises use a sophisticated sonar system to locate and track prey.

chapters.title: Food on the brain
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have discovered a neural code for food abundance.

chapters.title: Need not apply
chapters.impact_statement: Zebrafish can make their own sunscreen.

title: March 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about herpes, breweries, model organisms, social interactions in rats and traumatic brain injuries in flies.

chapters.title: Protecting against herpes
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have made a breakthrough in the search for a vaccine.

chapters.title: Sudden impact
chapters.impact_statement: What can experiments on flies teach us about traumatic brain injuries?

chapters.title: Biology in a brewery
chapters.impact_statement: Where there's beer, there's bacteria.

chapters.title: The wild frontier
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have discovered a neural code for food abundance.

chapters.title: A social network
chapters.impact_statement: Watching what happens in the brain of a rat during a social interaction.

title: February 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about TB, HIV, social behaviour in ants, genetics in baboons and a surprising twist to the handshake.

chapters.title: Taking a close look at TB
chapters.impact_statement: Whole genome sequencing is providing new insights into the spread of different lineages of TB.

chapters.title: There is more to a handshake than meets the eye
chapters.impact_statement: Sniffing our hand after a handshake may allow us to detect chemical signals produced by others.

chapters.title: Safety first
chapters.impact_statement: What are the side effects when Tenofovir gel is used as a prophylactic against HIV?

chapters.title: The division of labour in ants
chapters.impact_statement: Neuroscientists are studying the link between genetics and social behaviour in ants.

chapters.title: What baboons can tell us
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers are exploring the genetic architecture of gene expression in baboons and other primates.

title: January 2015
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about controlling sperm by optogenetics, hibernation, body clocks, enzyme structure, and a way to overcome stress-induced infertility.

chapters.title: Remote controlled sperm
chapters.impact_statement: Light can be used to control the motility of sperm.

chapters.title: Heating up in a hurry
chapters.impact_statement: Specially protected messenger RNA molecules allow hibernating squirrels to warm up quickly.

chapters.title: A second body clock
chapters.impact_statement: Dopamine drives an "ultradian" clock with a period of around four hours in mice.

chapters.title: Modelling molecules
chapters.impact_statement: Learning more about how enzymes work could lead to the design of new enzymes.

chapters.title: How stress causes infertility
chapters.impact_statement: Switching off the RFRP3 gene in the hypothalamus prevents stress-induced infertility in rats.

title: November/December 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about reproducibility, drug resistance, cells without walls, gene transfer, interspecies signalling, and stem cells.

chapters.title: Repeat performances
chapters.impact_statement: The Reproducibility Project: Cancer Biology will replicate selected experiments from 50 high-impact papers in preclinical cancer biology research.

chapters.title: The one and only
chapters.impact_statement: It may be possible to use one drug, rather than several, to tackle viral infections.

chapters.title: Off the wall
chapters.impact_statement: Some bacteria can survive and thrive despite not having a cell wall.

chapters.title: Spreading far and wide
chapters.impact_statement: The genes responsible for antibiotics can spread between all three of the domains of life.

chapters.title: Fatal attraction
chapters.impact_statement: A beetle pheromone that lures nematode worms to an insect host can also stop their development or even kill them outright.

chapters.title: Niche work
chapters.impact_statement: When an epithelial stem cell divides, why does one of the new cells remain a stem cell while the other becomes a specialized cell?

title: October 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about influenza pandemics, eating too much, cannabis and the brain, HIV cure research, and the evolution of sea squirts.

chapters.title: Preparing for pandemics
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers are exploring new ways to assess the risks posed to humans by non-human influenza viruses.

chapters.title: Food for thought
chapters.impact_statement: How do we know when we have eaten too much?

chapters.title: Missed connections
chapters.impact_statement: The role of cannabinoid receptors in the development of the brain is becoming clearer.

chapters.title: HIV's hidden reservoir
chapters.impact_statement: HIV-1 DNA could be a biomarker for disease progression.

chapters.title: Regulation rules
chapters.impact_statement: Different forms of regulation can lead to the formation of similar physical features.

title: August/September 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about the spread of the ebola virus, the financial costs of research misconduct, aging in yeast, grooming in flies, and symbiosis between bacteria and fungal cells.

chapters.title: The spread of ebola
chapters.impact_statement: Changes in lifestyles mean than new outbreaks of Ebola virus disease are likely to be very different from previous outbreaks.

chapters.title: Paying the price
chapters.impact_statement: A set of 149 papers that were retracted due to misconduct had been funded to the tune of $58m by the NIH.

chapters.title: The acid test
chapters.impact_statement: Why do some yeast cells grow old whereas others do not?

chapters.title: Keep it clean
chapters.impact_statement: A suppression hierarchy determines the order in which a fly cleans the different parts of its body.

chapters.title: Two against one
chapters.impact_statement: Bacteria and fungal cells join forces to cause rice seedling blight.

title: June/July 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about using photographs to diagnose rare genetic disorders, an unexpected benefit of exercise, hybridizing fish species, the mysteries of the MECP2 gene, and the risks and benefits of using gene drives to alter wild populations.

chapters.title: What's in a face?
chapters.impact_statement: Using a combination of computer vision and machine learning to analyze photographs of faces can assist in the diagnosis of rare genetic disorders.

chapters.title: Sight for sore eyes
chapters.impact_statement: Viewing a visual stimulus whilst running helps mice that have lost their sight in one eye to make a near-complete recovery.

chapters.title: Hybrid approach
chapters.impact_statement: How do different species remain distinct if they can mate with each other to produce hybrid offspring?

chapters.title: A tale of two domains
chapters.impact_statement: Why does too little MeCP2 cause Rett syndrome, while too much causes MECP2 duplication syndrome?

chapters.title: Making the most of gene drives
chapters.impact_statement: Gene drives could be used to eradicate diseases and support sustainable agriculture, but they must be handled with care.

title: May 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about the neuroscience of chewing, skin cancer, African sleeping sickness, and an ancient protein complex called TSET. eLife editor-in-chief Randy Schekman also shares his thoughts on scientific publishing.

chapters.title: Open and closed
chapters.impact_statement: Why don't we bite our tongues when we chew?

chapters.title: Small consolation
chapters.impact_statement: The immune response triggered by eczema may reduce the risk of skin cancer.

chapters.title: Catch me if you can
chapters.impact_statement: How the parasite that causes sleeping sickness keeps one step ahead of its host.

chapters.title: Finding a missing link
chapters.impact_statement: A protein complex called TSET sheds light on the evolution of trafficking pathways.

chapters.title: Open access, impact factors and more
chapters.impact_statement: eLife editor-in-chief Randy Schekman discusses scientific publishing.

title: April 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about neuropathic pain, gene therapy, insulin production, aging in worms, and how flatworms grow new body parts.

chapters.title: Getting to grips with pain
chapters.impact_statement: Drugs could treat neuropathic pain more effectively if they targeted more than one type of ion channel.

chapters.title: Target practice
chapters.impact_statement: Viruses have been used to deliver two types of nucleases into cells for targeted gene editing.

chapters.title: All change in the pancreas
chapters.impact_statement: Generating different types of hormone secreting cells from human tissue sources could lead to new treatments for diabetes.

chapters.title: Life goes on
chapters.impact_statement: Learning more about the genes that allow flatworms to regenerate organs and tissue after amputation.

chapters.title: Old before their time
chapters.impact_statement: A protein that regulates metabolism in worms also helps to protect them from the effects of aging.

title: March 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we hear about the mating habits of flies, radiation resistance in bacteria, how insects learned to smell, and the Hawaiian bobtail squid..

chapters.title: Vive la résistance
chapters.impact_statement: Single mutations in three genes can increase the ability of E. coli to survive ionizing radiation by a factor of 1000.

chapters.title: Buzz off
chapters.impact_statement: Male flies rub chemicals called TAGs onto female flies during mating to make them less attractive to other males.

chapters.title: A twist in the tail
chapters.impact_statement: The Hawaiian bobtail squid and V. fischeri bacteria are the best of friends.

chapters.title: Up in the air
chapters.impact_statement: The receptors that allow insects to smell various chemicals probably evolved around the time they developed the ability to fly.

title: February 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we learn more about sleep, super Spy chaperones, swimming bacteria, orphan genes and the neuroscience of birdsong.

chapters.title: And so to sleep
chapters.impact_statement: A protein called RYE – short for Redeye - has a central role in the regulation of sleep.

chapters.title: Flexible friends
chapters.impact_statement: Chaperones are proteins that help other proteins to fold properly, and being flexible makes them better at this task.

chapters.title: Twisting and turning
chapters.impact_statement: Bacteria employ a sophisticated method to ensure that they swim in a particular direction.

chapters.title: The mystery of orphan genes
chapters.impact_statement: Orphan genes appear and disappear quite quickly in Drosophila, leaving the total number of genes roughly constant.

chapters.title: Lost in music
chapters.impact_statement: Songbirds stop listening to themselves when they start to sing.

title: January 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss rats, ants, sharks and rays, and the pathogen that causes corn smut in maize.

chapters.title: Lost at sea
chapters.impact_statement: Over half of all shark and ray species are “threatened or near threatened” according to new estimates.

chapters.title: Why rats don't rat on other rats
chapters.impact_statement: A rat will help another rat if it is familiar with that type of rat, even if it has not met the actual rat before.

chapters.title: Complex problem solved
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have worked out the structure of a protein complex that is involved in the destruction of T helper cells by HIV.

chapters.title: Into the maize
chapters.impact_statement: The pathogen that causes corn smut in maize employs a sophisticated strategy to increase its virulence.

chapters.title: Evolution at work in ants
chapters.impact_statement: The body shapes of queen ants and worker ants have evolved in different ways to reflect their different roles.

title: December 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss the growing problem of drug resistance, severe brain damage, sugar versus sweetener, public goods dilemmas, and the evolution of translation machinery in cells.

chapters.title: Resistant to change
chapters.impact_statement: Resistance to antimicrobial drugs is not driven solely by the excessive use of these drugs.

chapters.title: Awakened by a sleeping pill
chapters.impact_statement: Why do some patients with severe brain injury become more alert after treatment with the sleeping pill zolpidem?

chapters.title: Life is sweet
chapters.impact_statement: How is the brain able to tell the difference between natural sugar and artificial sweetener?

chapters.title: Public goods dilemmas
chapters.impact_statement: Mathematical biologists are exploring the origins of cooperation in microbes.

chapters.title: Change of expression
chapters.impact_statement: Rapid changes in the genes for transfer RNA have been observed in experiments on yeast.

title: November 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss doing protein crystallography with electrons, the discovery of a receptor for carbon dioxide, new insights into arthritis, how the brain responds to a missing hand, and the best shape for whiskers.

chapters.title: Gently does it for crystallography
chapters.impact_statement: Very cold weak electron beams have been used to collect large numbers of diffraction patterns from protein microcrystals.

chapters.title: If your blood gets too acidic you will die
chapters.impact_statement: Carbon dioxide could be involved in processes as diverse as breathing, hearing and reproduction.

chapters.title: A gut feeling about arthritis
chapters.impact_statement: The gut microbiota of patients with rheumatoid arthritis is enriched in microbes belonging to the Prevotella genus.

chapters.title: How the brain moves on
chapters.impact_statement: In individuals with a missing hand, the area of the brain responsible for that hand learns to control the remaining hand or the residual limb.

chapters.title: Why do rodents have cone-shaped whiskers?
chapters.impact_statement: Conical whiskers allow mammals that live in tunnels and other enclosed spaces to learn more about their surroundings.

title: October 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss how chimpanzees use conceptual metaphors, the hyperactivation of spermatozoa, the use of bacteria to estimate the time of death, stem cells and smoking, and a new type of bacteria.

chapters.title: Sperm BerserKers
chapters.impact_statement: Human sperm cells rely on an unusual type of potassium ion channel.

chapters.title: A microbial clock
chapters.impact_statement: Measurements of bacteria could have applications in forensic science.

chapters.title: Welcome to Melainabacteria
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have found evidence for a new phylum of bacteria.

chapters.title: Tracking single stem cells
chapters.impact_statement: The epithelium that lines our airways is maintained by a population of basal cells.

chapters.title: Chimpanzees get conceptual
chapters.impact_statement: The use of metaphorical concepts is not unique to humans.

title: September 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss how flatworms can grow new heads and tails, how photosynthesis has evolved over time, social interactions between mice, the properties of undead cells, and interactions between steroids and genes.

chapters.title: How flatworms regenerate tissue
chapters.impact_statement: How are organisms such as planarians able to grow new heads and tails?

chapters.title: The evolution of photosynthesis
chapters.impact_statement: Computational techniques have shed fresh light on how C4 photosynthesis evolved from C3 photosynthesis.

chapters.title: Social interactions in mice
chapters.impact_statement: Mice that grow up in environments with lots of stimuli are less social and more territorial than mice that grow up in more spartan surroundings.

chapters.title: Undead cells and cell death at a distance
chapters.impact_statement: Cells undergoing programmed cell death release signals that trigger apoptosis in distant cells.

chapters.title: Turning transcription on and off in single cells
chapters.impact_statement: How much steroid is needed to switch on a single gene?

title: August 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss the cocktail party effect, how psuedogene RNA has a role in the immune response, new insights into the genetic origins of a common form of blindness, research into individual responses to the flu vaccine, and the origins of the tropical disease schistosomiasis.

chapters.title: The cocktail party effect
chapters.impact_statement: Neuroscientists are getting closer to understanding how people can distinguish where different sounds come from in noisy environments.

chapters.title: Turning on pseudogenes
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have discovered a role for pseudogenes – which are thought to be dead genes – in regulating the immune response.

chapters.title: Looking into blindness
chapters.impact_statement: Experiments with stem cells are shedding new light on the genetic origins of one of the most common forms of inherited blindness.

chapters.title: How genes influence our response to the flu vaccine
chapters.impact_statement: Changes in gene expression could be used to predict whether individuals will respond successfully to the influenza vaccine.

chapters.title: Stem cells and tropical diseases
chapters.impact_statement: Genetic techniques are providing new insights into the origins of schistosomiasis, a tropical disease that is caused by parasitic flatworms.

title: July 2013
impact_statement: In this issue of the eLife podcast we discuss plants performing arithmetic division, the evolutionary dynamics of cancer, single-molecule measurements in the immune system, why blood vessels don’t grow in the retina, how to make science count in government, a sensor for ammonium, and the evolution of gene regulation.

chapters.title: Plants performing arithmetic division
chapters.impact_statement: Plants use chemical reactions to calculate the rate at which they can use up their stores of starch during the night and still have some left at sunrise.

chapters.title: The evolutionary dynamics of cancer
chapters.impact_statement: A mathematical model has predicted that cancer drugs given in combination are more effective than the same drugs given in sequence.

chapters.title: Why blood vessels don't grow in the retina
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have identified a receptor that prevents blood vessels forming in the outer retina—a process that can lead to blindness—by sequestering a crucial growth factor.

chapters.title: Single-molecule measurements in the immune system
chapters.impact_statement: Single-molecule measurements in living cells have revealed that a single foreign peptide is able to activate a single T cell.

chapters.title: And there's more
chapters.impact_statement: eLife features editor Peter Rodgers discusses a topical Point of View article by Ian Boyd, chief scientific adviser to the Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs in the UK, plus research articles on a sensor for measuring extracellular ammonium and a study of the evolution of gene regulation in yeast.

title: June 2013
impact_statement: Welcome to the first eLife podcast, which covers topics as diverse as the origins of multicellularity, what modern sequencing technology can tell us about the potato famines of the 1840s, the discovery of the receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses, the effect of fog on the behaviour of car drivers, and the evolution of chromatin.

chapters.title: The origins of multicellularity
chapters.impact_statement: Extremely low concentrations of a molecule produced by bacteria can cause single-celled organisms to form colonies, which suggests that bacteria might have influenced the origin of multicellularity in animals

chapters.title: What modern sequencing technology can tell us about the potato famines of the 1840s
chapters.impact_statement: The strain of P. infestans that caused the Great Famine in the late 1840s has been identified by sequencing the genomes of samples collected in the 19th century.

chapters.title: All about eLife
chapters.impact_statement: eLife deputy editor Fiona Watt explains why eLife was launched and what it hopes to achieve.

chapters.title: A receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses
chapters.impact_statement: The identification of a functional receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses could lead to new strategies for tackling these diseases.

chapters.title: The effect of fog on car drivers
chapters.impact_statement: Virtual reality experiments show that motorists slow down when driving in fog, but they speed up when visibility is reduced equally at all distances.

chapters.title: The evolution of chromatin
chapters.impact_statement: Similarities between the chromatin in archaea and eukaryotes suggest that it might have been involved in gene regulation before its role in DNA packaging evolved.
